_exec_summary.SummaryText:
UNION CARBIDE CORPORATION a wholly owned subsidiary of The Dow Chemical Company 



INSTITUTE SITE



The Union Carbide (UCC) facilities at South Charleston, Institute, Technology Park, and New Yard share leveraged support and management and are collectively called West Virginia Operations (WVO).



ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES



WVO is strongly committed to employee, public, and environmental safety. This commitment is demonstrated by our comprehensive accidental release prevention program that covers areas such as design, installation, operating procedures, maintenance, and employee training associated with the processes at our facility. It is our policy to implement appropriate controls to prevent possible releases of regulated substances. If such a release should occur, highly trained emergency response personnel are at hand to control and mitigate the effects of the release. We are also an active member of the Kanawha/Putnam Emergency Planning Committee which provides additional emergency response expertise.





STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES



The Institute Site is a manufacturing facility that annually produces many specialty chemical products for Union Carbide. Most products are intermediates used in other processes or sold to customers who convert them into finished products. 



There are currently 4 RMP regulated substances present in 5 covered processes at the site. UCC handles and stores threshold quantities of the following RMP-regulated toxic substances at the Institute site:

Ethylene Oxide

Anhydrous Ammonia

Ethylenediamine



UCC handles and stores threshold quantities of the following RMP-regulated flammable substance at the Institute site:

Isopentane



An additional RMP covered process has been created for the Institute Site called Transportation Storage, which involves ethylene oxide rail cars that have been transported into the site and parked on the rail spurs until needed at the unloading rac

k.  These rail cars are collectively addressed as a separate process since these rail cars are not under active shipping papers and are not yet connected to the EO Distribution system.



Maximum threshold inventory quantities of ethylene oxide have increased for RMP Processes at Institute due to the shared quantity associated with interconnecting pipeline to the distribution header, storage tanks, and railcar unloading rack (in addition to in-process quantities).  Additionally, ethylene oxide quantities have been revised for the 2014 RMP resubmittal according to the following:



?    Estimated EO quantities from connected rail cars at the unloading rack have increased due to average rail car capacity increase.

?    EO storage tank capacity has been revised to reflect more accurate estimation methods, which resulted in a decrease.



Three toxic alternative scenarios are included for this resubmittal.  The 2009 RMP provided four alternative scenarios including two ethylene oxide alternative scenarios.  Only one toxic alternative scenario is required for each RMP toxic chemical above threshold, therefore the redundant scenario was removed.



The toxic worst-case scenario for the Institute Site has been revised.  The EO storage tanks at the Institute Site are completely buried under an earthen mound topped with an impervious outer layer.  Upon release a limited amount of the liquid will flash; the unique mounding approach will help prevent spreading of the remaining liquid release and provides mitigating effects typically associated with permanently installed diking.  As the RMPComp tool does not consider the impact a dike can have on the release of a liquefied gas under pressure, UCC determined that utilization of the PHAST Version 6.7 model is best suited to provide representative worst-case release estimations for an Institute EO tank. 



Revision:  EO storage tanks have historically served as the basis for the worst-case scenario due to the largest quantity of the c

hemical associated with the tanks and greatest offsite impact.  The above-mentioned modeling efforts in 2014 focused on applying release mitigating credits to the covering of the EO storage tanks, which effectively reduced the distance-to-endpoint release impact.  Due to these modeling credits of the tank coverings, the EO rail car at Transportation Storage becomes the worst-case scenario, while being the second largest volume of ethylene oxide at the site.  The RMP is being resubmitted to reflect this change.



The flammable worst-case scenario for the Institute Site has been revised.  Isopentane is no longer transported into the Site via rail car, and is now utilizing tank trucks.  Where tank trucks have a much lower storage capacity than a rail car, the isopentane storage tank now becomes the source of largest quantity in a single vessel or piping, and is the basis for the worst-case scenario.



FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

UCC facilities at the Institute site have had an excellent record of preventing accidental releases over the last 5 years. Due to our stringent release prevention policies, there have been no significant releases with off-site impact as defined by the RMP rule of regulated substances, during this period.





GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM



Union Carbide's general accident prevention program consists of compliance with the EPA RMP rule, OSHA's PSM standard, and implementation of Dow's Operating Discipline Management System and standards. Key elements include:



Process Safety Information

We maintain detailed records of safety information that describe the chemical hazards, operating parameters

and equipment designs associated with all covered processes. Examples include, but are not limited to,

Material Safety Data Sheets for all the hazardous chemicals, equipment design specification sheets, and

reactive chemicals test results. This information is maintained up-to-date and is available to operating

personnel.



Proces

s Hazard Analysis

Our facility conducts comprehensive studies to ensure that hazards associated with our processes are

identified, evaluated, and controlled efficiently. The methodologies used to carry out these analyses may

include: Checklists, What If/Checklists (combined), Hazard and Operability Studies (HAZOPs), Reactive

Chemical/Process Hazard Analyses, Chemical Exposure Index, Fire & Explosion Index, and Layers of Protection

Analyses. The studies are undertaken by a team of qualified personnel with expertise in engineering and

process operations and are revalidated at regular intervals. Any findings related to the hazard analysis are

addressed in a timely manner.



Operating Procedures

For the purposes of safely conducting activities within our covered processes, WVO maintains written

operating procedures. These procedures address various modes of operation such as initial startup, normal

operations, temporary operations, emergency shutdown, emergency operations, normal shutdown and

startup after a turnaround. The information is regularly reviewed and is readily accessible to operators

involved in the processes.



Training

WVO has a comprehensive training program in place to ensure that employees who are operating processes

are competent in the operating procedures associated with these processes. Refresher training is provided

on a continuing basis.



Mechanical Integrity

WVO carries out a documented Planned Preventative Maintenance Program (PPM) which provides checks on

process equipment to ensure proper operations. Process equipment examined by these checks includes, but

is not limited to: pressure vessels, storage tanks, piping systems, relief and vent systems, emergency

shutdown systems, controls, pumps, and compressors. Maintenance operations are carried out by qualified

personnel with training in maintenance practices. Furthermore, these personnel are offered specialized

training as needed. Any equipment deficiencies identified b

y the maintenance checks are corrected in a safe

and timely manner.



Management of Change

WVO facilities require management of modifications to process equipment, procedures, raw materials, and

processing conditions other than "like for like", by identifying, documenting, and reviewing them prior to

implementation of changes.  Process operators, maintenance personnel or any other employee whose job

tasks are affected by a modification in process conditions are promptly made aware of and receive training

prior to the modification.



Pre-startup Reviews

Pre-start up safety reviews related to new processes and to modifications in established processes are conducted at WVO. These reviews are conducted to confirm that construction, equipment, operating and

maintenance procedures are suitable for safe startup prior to placing equipment into operation.



Compliance Audits

Self assessments and audits are conducted on a regular basis to determine whether the provisions set out

under the RMP rule are being implemented. Audits are conducted using established schedules and any

corrective actions required as a result of the audits are undertaken in a safe and prompt manner.



Incident Investigation

WVO promptly investigates any incident that has resulted in, or could reasonably result in a significant release of a regulated substance. These investigations are undertaken to identify the situation leading to the incident as well as any corrective actions to prevent the release from reoccurring. All reports are retained for a minimum of 5 years.



Employee Participation

UCC believes that process safety management and accident prevention is a team effort. UCC employees working in Institute plants are strongly encouraged to express their views concerning accident prevention issues and to recommend improvements. In addition, our employees have access to all information created as part of the facility's implementation of the RMP rule, including information resulting

from process hazard analyses in particular.



Contractors

WVO hires contractors to perform some specialized maintenance, distribution, and construction activities. Prior to

selecting a contractor, a thorough evaluation of safety performance of the contractor is performed. WVO has

a strict policy of informing the contractors of known potential hazards related to the contractor's work and

the processes he/she may encounter while on site. Contractors are also informed of all the procedures for

emergency response should an accidental release of a regulated substance occur.





EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM



The emergency response program provides the essential planning and training for effectively protecting workers, the public, and the environment during emergency situations. Detailed emergency response plans are developed and coordinated with the Kanawha/Putnam Emergency Planning Committee and the community.



The Institute site has a written emergency response plan to deal with accidental releases of hazardous materials. The plan includes all aspects of emergency response including adequate first aid and medical treatment, evacuations, notification of local emergency response agencies and the public, as well as post- incident decontamination of affected areas. The plan is promptly updated to reflect any pertinent changes taking place within our processes that would require a modified emergency response.



To ensure proper functioning, quarterly emergency drills are conducted to enhance skills and tactics for responding to an accidental chemical release. Critiques are held on drills and actual events. Emergency response equipment is regularly inspected and serviced.



Kanawha/Putnam EPC is the Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC) with which Institute's emergency plan has been coordinated and verified.



PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

We continue to implement projects to improve process safety as opportunities are identified via external regulatory c
hanges and/or internal process safety program changes or evaluations.
